body.value: Charles Reznikoff introduces “Salmon and Red Wine”.
collection of Chinese verse translated in English
"Poetry presents the thing in order to convey the feeling.  It should be precise about the thing and reticent about the feeling"
Reads first line “Salmon and red wine”.
Introduces first line “I have neither the time nor the weaving skill, perhaps...”.
second poem in the same theme
Reads first line “I have neither the time nor the weaving skill, perhaps...”.
Introduces unknown poem, first line “The winter afternoon darkens...”
group of poems about New York
Reads unknown poem, first line “The winter afternoon darkens...”.
Reads unknown poem, first line “The peddler who goes from shop to shop...”.
Reads unknown poem, first line “The shopgirls leave their work...”.
from the poem        “Autobiography: New York” in By the Waters of Manhattan (New Directions, 1962)
Reads unknown poem, first line “Showing a torn sleeve...”.
Reads “Two girls of twelve or so at a table”.
Reads first line “I am always surprised to meet...”
Reads unknown poem, first line “Rails in the subway”.
Reads unknown poem, first line “This subway station, with its electric lights”.
Reads unknown poem, first line “Among the heaps of brick and plaster lies...”.
Reads unknown poem, first line “The sky is [a peculiar] blue...”.
Reads first line “Frasier, I think, tells of a Roman...”.
Reads first line “The dogs that walk with me...”.
from By the Waters of Manhattan
Reads first line “One of my sentinels, a tree...”.
Reads poem, first line “I have not even been in the fields...”.
Reads poem, first line “How grey are you, no white...”.
Reads poem, first line “Blurred sight, and trembling fingers...”.
Reads poem, fist line “If my days were like the ant’s...”.
Reads poem, first line “Our nightingale, the clock...”.
Reads poem, first line “The clock on the bookcase ticks...”.
Reads poem, first line “My hair was caught in the wheels of a clock...”.
Reads poem, first line “Of course we must die...”.
Reads poem, first line “Now it is cold...”.
Reads poem, first line “It had been snowing at night...”.
Reads poem, first line “Hardly a breath of wind...”.
Reads poem, first line: “After I had worked all day...”.
Introduces group called ‘religious’, poem called “Meditations on the Fall and Winter Holidays”.
Reads “New Year’s” from “Meditations on the Fall and Winter Holidays”.
from “Meditations on the Fall and Winter         Holidays” from Inscriptions: 1944-1956 (1959)
victory of Maccabees over Syrians in 150 BCE
Reads poem, first line, “The lamps are burning in the synagogue...”
Introduces poem, first line “Tilda was just a child...”.
Reads poem, first line “Tilda was just a child...”.
Reads poem, first line, “Years ago, a company procured a body of land...”.
written at the beginning of the rise of Hitler
ancient blessing in the Jewish ritual
quote from James Parks’ History of the Jewish People
Introduces “After Reading Translations of Ancient Texts on Stone and Clay”.
from Going To and Fro and Walking Up and Down (1941)
Reads “After Reading Translations of Ancient Texts on Stone and Clay”.
Introduces “As I was wandering with my unhappy thoughts...”
Reads “As I was wandering with my unhappy thoughts...”.
Reads “The young fellow walks about with nothing to do”.
Reads “On a Sunday, when the place was closed”.
included in By the Waters of Manhattan
Reads “The company had advertised for men...”.
Introduces “He had with him a bag”.
Reads “He had with him a bag”.
Introduces “On a seat in the subway”.
Reads “On a seat in the subway”.
Reads “These days, the papers in the street...”.
Introduces “Because I saw the desolation of Zion...”.
Reads “Because I saw the desolation of Zion”.
Unknown introducer thanks Charles Reznikoff, announces next reading: Daryl Hine on December 1st.
